snippet: The fact that an American prisoner in North Korea was allowed to send letters to his family suggests that the reclusive state is open to negotiations about him.
abstract: Family of Kenneth Bae, American sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in North Korea, receives letters from him in the mail, telling them that his health is worse and asking them to press United States government to help secure his release; experts say fact that letters were delivered suggests that the reclusive state is open to negotiations about him.

byline.contributor: Choe Sang-hun contributed reporting from Seoul.

lead_paragraph: The fact that an American prisoner in North Korea was allowed to send letters to his family suggests that the reclusive state is open to negotiations about him.

headline.main: Inmate’s Letters Hint at North Korea Opening
